title: Testing models for fully and partially stripped low-mass stars with Gaia: Implications for hot subdwarfs, binary RR Lyrae, and black hole impostors
summary: When low-mass ($\lesssim 2$ $M_{\odot}$) red giants lose their envelopes to a companion just before the helium flash, the resulting mass transfer can produce binaries hosting hot subdwarfs, horizontal branch stars, and undermassive red clump stars. Recent work predicts a continuum of such products, from fully stripped hot subdwarfs to partially stripped horizontal branch and red clump stars, and suggests that young, metal-rich RR Lyrae can form when partial stripping leaves a helium-burning star in the instability strip. To enable direct comparison with observations, we model these binaries in a simulated Milky Way-like galaxy with a realistic metallicity-dependent star formation history and 3D dust map, generate epoch astrometry using Gaia's scanning law, and fit it with the cascade of astrometric models applied in Gaia DR3. We compare the simulated population to DR3 observations of hot subdwarfs, RR Lyrae, and red giants with high astrometric mass functions. The model significantly overpredicts the number of hot subdwarfs with astrometric binary solutions, partly because the predicted flux ratios are more unequal than observed. It also predicts $\gtrsim 100$ RR Lyrae with DR3 astrometric orbital solutions, while none are observed. We conclude that RR Lyrae in au-scale binaries may be substantially rarer than predicted. In contrast, the model plausibly explains the population of red clump stars with high astrometric mass functions, which we interpret as potential black hole impostors. We predict that $\sim 10 \times$ more stripped-star binaries will be detectable in DR4, whose sensitivity to longer periods will more strongly test wide-orbit systems.

AI.tldr: Study simulates binary evolution products (hot subdwarfs, RR Lyrae, red clump stars) from low-mass red giants stripped before helium flash, compares to Gaia DR3 observations, finds overprediction of hot subdwarfs and RR Lyrae binaries, but plausible explanation for red clump stars with high mass functions.
AI.motivation: To enable direct comparison between theoretical predictions of binary evolution products (hot subdwarfs, horizontal branch stars, undermassive red clump stars) from low-mass red giants stripped before helium flash and actual Gaia DR3 observations, using realistic Milky Way simulations with metallicity-dependent star formation and 3D dust.
AI.method: Model binary evolution in simulated Milky Way-like galaxy with realistic metallicity-dependent star formation history and 3D dust map; generate epoch astrometry using Gaia's scanning law; fit with cascade of astrometric models applied in Gaia DR3; compare simulated population to DR3 observations of hot subdwarfs, RR Lyrae, and red giants with high astrometric mass functions.
AI.result: Model significantly overpredicts number of hot subdwarfs with astrometric binary solutions (predicted flux ratios more unequal than observed); predicts ≥100 RR Lyrae with DR3 astrometric orbital solutions but none observed; plausibly explains population of red clump stars with high astrometric mass functions as potential black hole impostors.
AI.conclusion: RR Lyrae in au-scale binaries may be substantially rarer than predicted; model provides plausible explanation for red clump stars with high mass functions; predicts ~10× more stripped-star binaries will be detectable in Gaia DR4, whose sensitivity to longer periods will more strongly test wide-orbit systems.

title: Calibration of the [C/N] and [Y/Mg] chemical clocks with asteroseismic ages from the TESS space mission
summary: Context. Stellar ages are typically very difficult to estimate for field stars. New empirical methods, based on abundance ratios of chemical elements, are emerging and need to be calibrated. Aims. Our main aim is to contribute to revealing relations between [C/N] and [Y/Mg] ratios and stellar ages by determining astroseismic ages and non-local thermodynamic equilibrium (NLTE) abundances, and accounting for stellar evolutionary stages and birth places in the Galaxy. Methods. We searched for solar pulsations in a sample of 1250 bright F, G, and K giants using data from the TESS space telescope and determined asteroseismic ages using the BASTA and PARAM codes. For the [Y/Mg] relations with age, we determined abundances accounting for deviations from the local thermodynamic equilibrium. For the [C/N] relations with age, we separated stars according to their evolutionary stages. Results. We determined asteroseismic ages for 218 giants and derived [Y/Mg] and [C/N] relations with age for subsamples of stars in three regions of the Galactic thin disc and the thick disc. Conclusions. The [Y/Mg]-age relation exhibits a clear radial dependence across the Galactic disc, with a steeper trend in the outer disc, progressively flatter relations towards the inner disc, and a very flat trend in the thick disc. NLTE abundances of Mg and especially of Y have to be used in order to obtain a more precise stellar age evaluation from [Y/Mg] ratios. When using [C/N] abundance ratios as stellar age indicators, evolutionary stages of stars have to be taken into account.

AI.tldr: The paper establishes empirical relations between chemical abundance ratios ([C/N] and [Y/Mg]) and stellar ages using asteroseismic ages from TESS data, revealing Galactic radial dependence and evolutionary stage effects.
AI.motivation: Stellar ages are difficult to estimate for field stars, and emerging empirical methods based on chemical abundance ratios need calibration. The study aims to reveal relations between [C/N] and [Y/Mg] ratios and stellar ages by determining accurate asteroseismic ages and accounting for stellar evolutionary stages and Galactic birth places.
AI.method: Analyzed 1250 bright F, G, and K giants using TESS data to detect solar pulsations. Determined asteroseismic ages using BASTA and PARAM codes. Derived [Y/Mg] relations using NLTE abundances to account for deviations from local thermodynamic equilibrium. Separated stars by evolutionary stages for [C/N] relations. Studied subsamples in three regions of the Galactic thin disc and thick disc.
AI.result: Determined asteroseismic ages for 218 giants. Found that the [Y/Mg]-age relation shows clear radial dependence across the Galactic disc: steeper trend in outer disc, progressively flatter towards inner disc, and very flat in thick disc. NLTE abundances of Mg and especially Y are essential for precise age evaluation from [Y/Mg]. Evolutionary stages must be considered when using [C/N] as age indicators.
AI.conclusion: Chemical abundance ratios [Y/Mg] and [C/N] can serve as empirical stellar age indicators, but require careful consideration of Galactic position (radial dependence) and stellar evolutionary stages. NLTE abundances are crucial for accurate [Y/Mg]-based age determination, while evolutionary stage separation is essential for [C/N]-based age estimation.

title: On the Importance of the Convective Urca Process in 3D Simulations of a Simmering White Dwarf
comment: 19 pages, 12 figures, Accepted to the Astrophysical Journal
summary: Type Ia supernovae are bright thermonuclear explosions that are important to numerous areas of astronomy. However, the origins of these events are poorly understood. One proposed setting is that of a near Chandrasekhar mass white dwarf that undergoes runaway carbon burning in the core. During the thousand years leading up to the explosion, the white dwarf undergoes a simmering phase where slow carbon burning heats the core and drives convection. A poorly understood aspect of this phase is the convective Urca process, which links convection with weak nuclear reactions. We use the low Mach number code MAESTROeX to perform full 3D simulations as is required to accurately capture the turbulent convection. We present simulations with and without the A=23 convective Urca process, which have relaxed to a steady state. We characterize the effects of the convective Urca process on the neutrino losses, the nuclear energy generation, and the convective boundary. We find that the size of the convection zone is substantially reduced by the convective Urca process, though convection still extends past the Urca shell. Our findings on the structure of the convective zone and the compositional changes can be used to inform 1D stellar models that track the longer-timescale evolution.

AI.tldr: 3D simulations show convective Urca process in pre-supernova white dwarfs substantially reduces convection zone size but doesn't eliminate it, with implications for 1D stellar models.
AI.motivation: Type Ia supernovae origins are poorly understood, particularly the convective Urca process during the simmering phase where slow carbon burning drives convection in near-Chandrasekhar mass white dwarfs before explosion.
AI.method: Used low Mach number code MAESTROeX to perform full 3D simulations of convective Urca process (A=23) in pre-supernova white dwarfs, comparing simulations with and without Urca process after reaching steady state.
AI.result: Convective Urca process substantially reduces convection zone size but convection still extends past the Urca shell; affects neutrino losses, nuclear energy generation, and convective boundary structure.
AI.conclusion: Findings on convection zone structure and compositional changes provide crucial data for improving 1D stellar models that track longer-timescale evolution of pre-supernova white dwarfs.

title: Retarded Stellar Dynamo in Tidally Deformed M Dwarfs
comment: 7 figures and 1 table in main text; 5 tables and 1 figure in supplement. Accepted by SCPMA
summary: Current studies of stellar dynamos primarily focus on spherical stars, leaving their behavior in distorted stars largely unexplored. We utilize stars of varying distortions to examine the relation between stellar cycle periods ($P_{\rm cyc}$) and rotational periods ($P_{\rm rot}$), which are closely linked to dynamo processes. By analyzing a sample of tidally distorted M dwarfs in cataclysmic variables, we identify an anti-correlation between $P_{\rm cyc}$ and $P_{\rm rot}$, in contrast to the lack of such a relation in single M dwarfs. This means that stars with greater deformation have longer cycle periods, suggesting variations in dynamo behavior under non-spherical geometries. Our numerical simulations further reveal that, the thermal convection weakens in highly distorted stars, and subsequently, the differential rotation is also reduced. These effects may lengthen the conversion timescale between poloidal and toroidal magnetic fields, potentially explaining the newly discovered $P_{\rm cyc}$-$P_{\rm rot}$ relation in cataclysmic variables.

AI.tldr: Tidally distorted M dwarfs in cataclysmic variables show an anti-correlation between stellar cycle periods and rotational periods, contrasting with single M dwarfs, suggesting deformation affects dynamo processes by weakening convection and differential rotation.
AI.motivation: Current stellar dynamo studies focus primarily on spherical stars, leaving the behavior in distorted stars largely unexplored. Understanding how stellar deformation affects dynamo processes and the relationship between cycle periods and rotational periods is needed.
AI.method: Analyzed a sample of tidally distorted M dwarfs in cataclysmic variables to examine the P_cyc-P_rot relation. Conducted numerical simulations to investigate how stellar distortion affects thermal convection and differential rotation.
AI.result: Found an anti-correlation between P_cyc and P_rot in tidally distorted M dwarfs, contrasting with the lack of such relation in single M dwarfs. Numerical simulations revealed that thermal convection weakens in highly distorted stars, and differential rotation is reduced. Stars with greater deformation have longer cycle periods.
AI.conclusion: Stellar deformation alters dynamo behavior by weakening convection and differential rotation, which may lengthen the conversion timescale between poloidal and toroidal magnetic fields. This explains the newly discovered P_cyc-P_rot anti-correlation in cataclysmic variables and demonstrates that non-spherical geometries significantly affect stellar dynamo processes.

title: The DECam MAGIC Survey: Uncovering the Tidal Tails of the Crater II Dwarf Galaxy
comment: 27 pages, 14 figures, 2 tables, Submitted to ApJ, Data available via Zenodo at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.16804864
summary: Crater II (CraII), a large and low-density dwarf spheroidal galaxy, has unusual observed properties that are difficult to reproduce in cold dark matter simulations. Ongoing tidal disruption may help explain the discrepancies, as evidenced by the recent discovery of tidal tails. Here we present metallicity-sensitive narrowband photometry of the Ca II H and K lines from the Dark Energy Camera, covering $128$ deg$^2$ across the center and identified tidal tails of CraII as part of the Mapping the Ancient Galaxy in CaHK (MAGIC) survey. Our combined photometric metallicity, color-magnitude, proper motion, and parallax selections identify 162 CraII candidates. Of these, 37 candidates are located in the tidal tails which extend at least $7^\circ$ ($\sim 95$ kpc) from the center of CraII, suggesting it has lost $\gtrsim 25$% of its initial stellar mass. We confirm low contamination rates with dedicated control fields and highlight the extremely low surface brightness stellar features that can be uncovered with CaHK data, as faint as $\sim 36$ mag arcsec$^{-2}$. We also make the first detection of a metallicity gradient ($-0.34\pm0.17~{\rm dex}~{\rm deg}^{-1}$) in the center of the galaxy and infer a stream width of $w\sim 0.8^\circ$, roughly 50% larger than the CraII half-light radius. The detection of candidates in the most distant CraII pointings from its center implies that the tidal tails extend beyond our footprint. We compare the CraII stream to $N$-body models with "cored" and "cuspy" dark matter halo progenitors, determining that CraII's density profile is still ambiguous and warrants further modeling.

AI.tldr: CaHK photometry reveals extensive tidal tails around Crater II dwarf galaxy, showing ~25% stellar mass loss, metallicity gradient, and stream width larger than galaxy's half-light radius, with dark matter halo profile remaining ambiguous.
AI.motivation: Crater II dwarf spheroidal galaxy has unusual properties difficult to explain in cold dark matter simulations, and ongoing tidal disruption may help resolve discrepancies, as suggested by recent tidal tail discoveries.
AI.method: Used metallicity-sensitive narrowband Ca II H and K line photometry from Dark Energy Camera (128 deg² coverage) as part of MAGIC survey, combined with photometric metallicity, color-magnitude, proper motion, and parallax selections to identify 162 CraII candidates.
AI.result: Identified 37 candidates in tidal tails extending ≥7° (~95 kpc) from center, indicating ≥25% initial stellar mass loss; detected first metallicity gradient (-0.34±0.17 dex deg⁻¹) in galaxy center; measured stream width ~0.8°, ~50% larger than half-light radius; confirmed low contamination via control fields; revealed extremely low surface brightness features (~36 mag arcsec⁻²).
AI.conclusion: Tidal tails extend beyond survey footprint; comparison with N-body models shows CraII's dark matter density profile (cored vs. cuspy) remains ambiguous and requires further modeling despite extensive tidal disruption evidence.

title: Is Mira B a low mass white dwarf?
summary:
We report photometric observations in Johnson B and V bands of the short term variability (flickering) of Mira (omicron Ceti). The observations were performed during 7 nights in the period August - October 2025, in the course of the last minimum of the Mira pulsations. The observed peak-to-peak amplitude of the flickering is 0.11-0.28 mag in B band. For the flickering source we find luminosity in the range 0.10-0.46 L_sun. Using the amplitude-flux relation, we estimate an average luminosity of the accretion disc L_d = 0.91 +/- 0.28 L_sun.
  Assuming that the white dwarf accretes material through Wind Roche Lobe Overflow (WRLOF), we find that Mira B is a low mass white dwarf with M_wd = 0.24 +/- 0.04 M_sun accreting at a rate 6.8x10^{-9} M_sun/yr. This value of the mass is in the range of the extremely low mass white dwarfs.
  The data are available on Zenodo: zenodo.org/records/18756532

AI.tldr: Photometric observations of Mira's short-term variability reveal flickering with 0.11-0.28 mag amplitude in B band, indicating accretion onto a low-mass white dwarf companion through wind Roche lobe overflow.
AI.motivation: To study short-term variability (flickering) in Mira (omicron Ceti) during its pulsation minimum to understand accretion processes in the Mira AB binary system and characterize the properties of the white dwarf companion.
AI.method: Johnson B and V band photometric observations over 7 nights during August-October 2025, during Mira's pulsation minimum. Analysis of flickering amplitude, luminosity estimation using amplitude-flux relation, and modeling of accretion via Wind Roche Lobe Overflow (WRLOF) to determine white dwarf parameters.
AI.result: Flickering amplitude of 0.11-0.28 mag in B band; flickering source luminosity 0.10-0.46 L_sun; accretion disc luminosity L_d = 0.91 ± 0.28 L_sun. Mira B is a low-mass white dwarf with M_wd = 0.24 ± 0.04 M_sun accreting at 6.8×10⁻⁹ M_sun/yr, placing it in the extremely low mass white dwarf category.
AI.conclusion: The observed flickering confirms accretion onto Mira B, which is an extremely low mass white dwarf accreting via wind Roche lobe overflow from Mira's wind. This provides evidence for ongoing mass transfer in the Mira AB system and characterizes the companion's properties.

title: NOCTURNE. III. Unidentified variable emission in the nuclear regions of PKS 2153-69
comment: Submitted to Revista Mexicana de Astrofísica y Astronomía Serie de Conferencias, 4 pages
summary: Historically, the study of the central regions of Type 1 AGN has been limited by the combination of the host galaxy spectrum with strong emission from the accretion disk and NLR/BLR, which prevented us from accurately probing the galactic and AGN properties in the central regions. Integral field spectroscopy allows us to correct for this effect and study both the unobscured cores of AGN host galaxies as well as the uncontaminated spectra of their central engines with unprecedented precision. Using MUSE WFM observations, in this work, we present a combined method for modelling and subtracting QSO light in type-1 AGN alongside results for one such source, PKS 2153-68 (z=0.028), both jetted and gamma-ray emitting. After separating the host galaxy and AGN spectra, we discuss the discovery of an unresolved and yet-to-be-identified high-velocity ($\sim$25000 km/s) short timescale ($\leq$1 yr) variable emission, unlike anything observed in other variable AGN.

AI.tldr: Novel method using MUSE integral field spectroscopy to separate AGN and host galaxy light in Type 1 AGN, revealing unprecedented high-velocity variable emission in PKS 2153-68.
AI.motivation: Traditional studies of Type 1 AGN central regions are limited by contamination from host galaxy spectra combined with strong accretion disk and NLR/BLR emission, preventing accurate probing of both galactic and AGN properties in central regions.
AI.method: Uses MUSE WFM integral field spectroscopy observations with a combined method for modeling and subtracting QSO light in Type 1 AGN, enabling separation of host galaxy and AGN spectra.
AI.result: Application to PKS 2153-68 reveals discovery of unresolved high-velocity (~25000 km/s) short timescale (≤1 yr) variable emission, unlike anything observed in other variable AGN.
AI.conclusion: Integral field spectroscopy enables unprecedented precision in studying both unobscured AGN host galaxy cores and uncontaminated central engine spectra, revealing novel phenomena in AGN physics.

title: Sub-second cadence structure of optical flares on AD Leo
summary: Stellar flares are sudden brightenings caused by magnetic reconnection and are frequently observed on late-type stars. High-cadence photometry of flares provides valuable insights into the mechanisms of these events, yet such observations remain scarce. We seek to explore the sub-second fine structure of stellar flares and assess the information content in high-speed photometry. New 0.3 s-cadence photometry from a six-year-long observing campaign of the active M-dwarf AD Leo is presented. We use time--frequency analysis to detect quasi-periodic pulsations in the decay phase of flares. We explore statistical measures of time series complexity of the detected flares to quantify the information gain achievable with high-cadence photometry. We detect 42 flares in 211 hours of observations. The flare frequency distribution is consistent with the previous literature. We find no quasi-periodic pulsations with periods below a few seconds, and identify two candidate signals with periods around 1 and 3 min. Using different measures of complexity on the binned flare light curves we confirm the advantages of high observing cadence. However, we also find a plateau up to a binning of ~4--5 s for a few complex flares, suggesting that an exposure time of a few seconds is usually enough to retain most of the information carried by a single-filter observation. New photometric observations of AD Leo revealed sub-structures of flare light curves on the timescale of a few seconds, but we found no features on timescales below that.

AI.tldr: Analysis of 0.3s-cadence photometry from AD Leo reveals 42 flares with sub-second structure but no quasi-periodic pulsations below few seconds, suggesting optimal exposure times of 4-5s for retaining flare information.
AI.motivation: To explore sub-second fine structure of stellar flares and assess information content in high-speed photometry, addressing the scarcity of high-cadence observations of flare mechanisms.
AI.method: Six-year observing campaign of active M-dwarf AD Leo with 0.3s-cadence photometry, using time-frequency analysis to detect quasi-periodic pulsations and statistical measures of time series complexity on binned flare light curves.
AI.result: Detected 42 flares in 211 hours; flare frequency distribution consistent with literature; found no quasi-periodic pulsations below few seconds (two candidate signals at ~1 and 3 min); complexity analysis shows advantages of high cadence but plateau at 4-5s binning for complex flares.
AI.conclusion: High-cadence photometry reveals flare substructures on few-second timescales but no features below that; exposure times of few seconds are sufficient to retain most information in single-filter observations.

title: Galaxy and black hole coevolution in dark matter haloes not captured by cosmological simulations
comment: 71 pages, 6 main figures, 4 tables, and 23 Extended Data and Supplementary figures. Accepted for publication in Nature Astronomy
summary: Star formation in galaxies is governed by internal and environmental processes, yet their relative roles are not well understood. In particular, uncertainties in measurements of active galactic nuclei (AGN) host galaxies, combined with modeling limitations, obfuscate the impact of supermassive black hole feedback across environments and over time. Here we address this with a comprehensive analysis of ~60,000 nearby AGNs (z < 0.15 and new environment and halo-mass measurements for ~500,000 AGN and non-AGN host galaxies. This benchmark enables unified comparisons with three prominent cosmological simulations--SIMBA, TNG, and EAGLE--and reveals major, contrasting shortcomings. Simulations fail to reproduce observed trends linking star formation, quiescence, AGN luminosity, stellar mass, and halo mass. While simulations qualitatively capture that AGNs are more common in low-mass halos than in rich groups or clusters, detailed host demographics diverge strongly from observations. Partial agreement exists in the stellar mass distribution within large-scale structures, yet all simulations overproduce quenched low-mass satellites in massive halos, while misrepresenting quenched fractions of massive central galaxies and those in low-density environments, which are sensitive to feedback implementation. Improved AGN physics and modeling of multi-phase gas cooling and flows are required to capture the observed interplay between black holes, galaxies, and halos.

AI.tldr: Analysis of ~60,000 nearby AGNs reveals major discrepancies between observed galaxy properties and three prominent cosmological simulations (SIMBA, TNG, EAGLE), highlighting limitations in current AGN feedback modeling.
AI.motivation: To understand the relative roles of internal and environmental processes in star formation, particularly the impact of supermassive black hole feedback across different environments and cosmic time, given uncertainties in AGN host galaxy measurements and modeling limitations.
AI.method: Comprehensive analysis of ~60,000 nearby AGNs (z < 0.15) with new environment and halo-mass measurements for ~500,000 AGN and non-AGN host galaxies, enabling unified comparisons with three prominent cosmological simulations: SIMBA, TNG, and EAGLE.
AI.result: Simulations fail to reproduce observed trends linking star formation, quiescence, AGN luminosity, stellar mass, and halo mass. While simulations qualitatively capture that AGNs are more common in low-mass halos than in rich groups/clusters, detailed host demographics diverge strongly from observations. All simulations overproduce quenched low-mass satellites in massive halos while misrepresenting quenched fractions of massive central galaxies and those in low-density environments.
AI.conclusion: Improved AGN physics and modeling of multi-phase gas cooling and flows are required to capture the observed interplay between black holes, galaxies, and halos, as current simulations show major shortcomings in reproducing observed galaxy properties.
